answers.text:
Hi Anthony, 
Thank you for your question and while I have some resources may be of use to your I hope some of out Knowledge Network users are able to chime in and provide you with some first hand experiences.
-Where We Live: The Impact of How Communities Grow is an article that talks about how hard it can be to understand how changing populations can effect local governments. http://bookstore.icma.org/freedocs/mlgs/Where%20We%20Live.pdf
-This previously asked question about determining a model for future staffing needs has many answers from local government officials. http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/kn/Question/22891
-Eagan, Minnesota: Growth with Grace this is a case study that shows how this local government has been able to successfully deal with shifting population size over the past 30 years.http://bookstore.icma.org/freedocs/mlgs/Eagan%20Minnesota.pdf
We are always interested in adding new and innovative documents to the Knowledge Network so when you are finished with your study consider uploading it so other local governments can learn from it.
Best, 
Robin Saywitz 
ICMA Knowledge Network Intern
rsaywitz@icma.org

author: Tony Hunter
text:
My name is Anthony Hunter, and I am a current MPA student at the University of Arizona in Tucson. This semester I am working on an internship project for a smaller (~40K) municipality in the area. Essentially, my task is to craft a growth plan for different levels of population increase (50K, 75K, 100K, and 150K). I am to look closely at every department and town services function and see what will be needed at each level and how changes can best be implemented without disruption to town services.
My questions are related to the best practices research that I'll be needing to do for the project:
Are there reliable online or academic resources for best practices information? Or would approaching it on a city by city basis be more appropriate? Is there an entirely different way to go about it?
Also: if you have any examples of cities or towns that have experienced exponential growth and met the challenge successfully, I could sure use a few bread crumbs to make a trail out of. 
Thank you very much for taking the time to help.
Sincerely,
Anthony Hunter
MPA Student
The University of Arizona
title: Best practices for population growth
